Comments: Chinook salmon were monitored in the mainstem Anchor River below the confluence of the North/South forks using DIDSON sonar and/or resistance board weir and/or instream video during 2003–2012. Monitoring occurred throughout the run; except in 2003; when an expansion was applied. Aerial surveys also conducted during previous years; but they were found to be unreliable (Kerkvliet et al. 2016) so we did not include them in our analysis.

A series of floods rendered the mainstem Anchor River site unsuitable for escapement monitoring. A combination of mainstem DIDSON sonar and weir/video systems operated on both the North and South forks was used to assess escapement throughout the run in 2013.

DIDSON sonar and/or resistance board weirs equipped with instream video were used to monitor Chinook salmon escapement throughout the run on both the North and South forks of the Anchor River during 2014–2015.

DIDSON sonar and/or resistance board weirs equipped with instream video were used to monitor Chinook salmon escapement throughout the run on both the North and South forks of the Anchor River during 2014–2015.
Escapement was estimated from Aerial survey data unless otherwise specified. Escapement was not surveyed or monitored during years with no escapement value.

EscapementMethodDetail: Expansion of aerial surveys based on ratio of paired aerial survey and weir count data
Expansion of aerial surveys based on ratio of paired aerial survey and weir count data
Expansion of aerial surveys based on ratio of paired aerial survey and weir count data
Expansion of aerial surveys based on ratio of paired aerial survey and weir count data

Comments: Escapement not surveyed or monitored during years with no escapement value. No aerial survey conducted in 1989; however; in 1988; 1989; 1994; and 1995 a weir was operated on the Little Susitna River. Based on the relationship of Weirs to aerial surveys in 1988; 1994; and 1995; 50% of the 1989 Weir of 4;367 Chinook salmon was used for an index of escapement.
